intro: Tanarius seemannii, commonly known as the St. Helena orchid, is a rare and endemic flowering plant found exclusively on the island of St. Helena in the South Atlantic Ocean. It is a member of the Orchidaceae family and is characterized by its delicate, terrestrial growth habit. The plant produces small, pale greenish-yellow flowers with intricate structures typical of orchids. It thrives in moist, shaded environments, often growing in rocky crevices or among vegetation. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Tanarius seemannii is considered a vulnerable species.
